com.guidewire.ab.webservices.entity

Class ObjectFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.guidewire.ab.webservices.entity.ObjectFilter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    Deprecated. 
    The ObjectFilter class is deprecated. Instead, rewrite integration code as custom web service APIs for each integration point, defining most application logic within the web service. Before this release, external code requested large objects and used ObjectFilter to define arbitrary fields to return so that the data transfer is not too large. Instead, design your new custom web services to return only what is needed. You might want to create new Gosu classes or non-persistent business entities for some integration points to encapsulate data passed to the web service or returned from the web service.

    public class ObjectFilter
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    An ObjectFilter, given a graph of objects, will extract a subgraph of "interesting" objects. It is designed to be used in places such as webservices where returning a large graph of objects may lead to performance problems.

    At a lower level, an ObjectFilter represents a set of rules which are applied recursively to a object (which we will call the "root object"). Each ObjectFilter consists of an array of FieldFilter objects, and each FieldFilter object defines a one-to-many relation from an entity name to a list of field names. The graph described by a given ObjectFilter and root object is calculated using the following algorithm:

    1. Find the entity name for the current object.

    2. Look through the ObjectFilter for a FieldFilter whose entity name correponds to the entity name of the current object.

    3. If there is no such FieldFilter, set every property of the current object to null. object.

    4. Take the FieldFilter with the matching entity name (if there is more than one such FieldFilter, choose one of them arbitrarily)

    5. Fetch the list of field names from the FieldFilter

    6. Set each field on the current object to null unless the field's name appears in the FieldFilter's list of field names.

    7. Recursively apply this procedure to each object which is a property of the current object.

    Applying this procedure to the root object yields the directed graph.

    See Also:
